title: Refactor Carousel component to remove complex template logic
description:
The Carousel component has complex template logic with nested loops, conditional class bindings, and slide/navigation state management. Refactor to use computed signals for slide states and simplify slide rendering.

Complexity: High
Issues:
- Complex slide generation with nested loops and track positioning
- Multiple conditional class bindings for slide states (active, prev, next, transitioning)
- Nested template conditionals for navigation controls and indicators
- Manual transform calculations and transition timing in template
- Complex autoplay/pause state synchronization

Refactor Strategy:
- Extract slide position calculations to computed signals
- Create dedicated SlideState interface with computed properties
- Simplify track transform using signal-based position binding
- Replace manual navigation logic with declarative slide index signals
- Move autoplay timer management out of template lifecycle

title: Refactor Select component to remove complex template logic
description:
The Select component has complex template logic with nested loops, conditional class bindings, and option/filtering state management. Refactor to use computed signals for option states and simplify dropdown rendering.

Complexity: High
Issues:
- Complex option/group generation with nested loops
- Multiple conditional class bindings for option states (selected, disabled, highlighted, filtered)
- Nested template conditionals for optgroups and custom templates
- Manual focus/keyboard navigation state tracking
- Complex filtering logic intertwined with template

Refactoring approach:
- Extract OptionState interface with computed selected/disabled/highlighted signals
- Create OptionListService to manage flat option list with group awareness
- Replace nested *ngFor loops with single virtual scroll viewport
- Simplify keyboard navigation with focusedIndex signal and computed scroll position
- Move filtering logic to pure function with computed filteredOptions
- Extract option template into standalone OptionItem component
- Use content projection for custom option templates with fallback default

Acceptance criteria:
- No nested structural directives in main template
- All option states derived from signals
- Keyboard navigation uses signal-based state
- Filtering recomputes via effect, not manual trigger
- Group headers render via computed groupedOptions structure
- Custom templates work via TemplateRef injection

Testing notes:
- Verify keyboard navigation with groups and filtering
- Test custom template projection with signal inputs
- Confirm performance with 10k+ options via virtual scroll
- Check accessibility: aria-activedescendant, aria-selected updates

title: Refactor Table component to remove complex template logic
description:
The Table component has complex template logic with nested loops, conditional class bindings, and sorting/filtering state management. Refactor to use computed signals for row states and simplify data rendering.

Complexity: High
Issues:
- Complex row/cell generation with nested loops
- Multiple conditional class bindings for row states (selected, expanded, disabled)
- Nested template conditionals for cell rendering based on column types
- Inline sorting and filtering logic in templates
- Complex pagination calculations mixed with template structure

Goals:
- Extract row state computation into dedicated signals
- Simplify cell rendering with column configuration objects
- Move sorting/filtering logic to computed signals
- Create reusable cell renderer components for different data types
- Separate pagination state from template structure

Acceptance Criteria:
- Template contains no nested *ngFor loops with complex logic
- All row states computed via signals
- Column definitions drive rendering without template conditionals
- Sorting and filtering handled in component logic, not templates
- Pagination state managed through dedicated signal stores

title: Refactor Calendar component to remove complex template logic
description:
The Calendar component has complex template logic with nested loops, conditional class bindings, and date state management. Refactor to use computed signals for date states and simplify grid rendering.

Recommended Fix: Simplify grid rendering by using computed signals for date states

title: Refactor Combobox Component Template Complexity
description:
Refactor the ZardComboboxComponent to reduce template complexity and improve maintainability. The current template has high complexity with duplicate option rendering logic, deep nesting (4+ levels), and scattered ARIA attributes.

## Current Issues

1. **High Template Complexity**: Lines 64-159 contain deeply nested @for and @if blocks
2. **Duplicate Code**: Option rendering logic is repeated 3 times (grouped with label, grouped without label, flat options)
3. **No Unit Tests**: The component lacks proper test coverage
4. **Maintainability**: Complex structure makes future enhancements difficult

## Proposed Solution

Extract a ZardComboboxOptionComponent to handle individual option rendering, eliminating duplicate code and reducing nesting depth.

## Acceptance Criteria

- Template nesting depth reduced from 4+ levels to maximum 2 levels
- No duplicate option rendering logic
- All existing functionality preserved
- All demos work correctly (default, grouped, disabled, form)
- New unit tests added for extracted components
- Accessibility attributes maintained
- No regression in keyboard navigation
- Code coverage maintained or improved

## Files to Modify

- combobox.component.ts - Simplify template, use new option component
- combobox-option.component.ts - NEW - Extracted option component
- index.ts - Export new component
- combobox.component.spec.ts - NEW - Add missing tests
- combobox-option.component.spec.ts - NEW - Tests for new component

## Implementation Plan

See plans/combobox-refactoring-plan.md for detailed implementation strategy.

## References

- Component: libs/zard/src/lib/shared/components/combobox/combobox.component.ts
- Plan: plans/combobox-refactoring-plan.md
